entry.author: By Chris Reiter, Brian Parkin and Andreas Cremer
entry.headline: General Motors Says Opel Unit Attracted Three Bids
entry.body:
General Motors Corp. (GM), which is selling its Opel unit while preparing for a probable June 1 bankruptcy, attracted three bids for the German division, according to Chris Preuss, a spokesman for GM Europe.

Fiat SpA (F), Italy''s largest carmaker, presented an offer for GM''s Opel and Vauxhall divisions in Europe as part of a plan to combine with them and with Chrysler LLC in the U.S., the Turin-based manufacturer said today in a statement.

Magna International Inc. (MG), a Canadian car-parts maker, and RHJ International (RHJI) SA, a Brussels-based investment firm started by Ripplewood Holdings LLC founder Timothy Collins, submitted detailed offers for Opel to the German government, said a state official, speaking on condition that he not be identified because the bids are confidential.

GM faces bankruptcy if it doesn''t reorganize by June 1 to meet terms for U.S. government loans. The Detroit-based carmaker is willing to sell a majority stake in cash-strapped Opel, which is based in the Frankfurt suburb of Ruesselsheim and has assembly plants in countries including Spain, Belgium and Poland. Vauxhall builds cars in the U.K.

Significant Progress''

German Chancellor Angela Merkel''s government made significant progress yesterday in talks with state-owned banks including KfW Group toward securing bridge loans of at least 1 billion euros ($1.38 billion) for Opel, Juergen Reinholz, economy minister of the state of Thuringia, said yesterday in a phone interview. A decision on a winning bid may take until June, he added.

Government officials are likely to meet this week to discuss the Opel bids and will convene as often as they need to find a solution very quickly, Labor Minister Olaf Scholz told reporters in Berlin today.

GM rose 18 cents, or 14 percent, to $1.45 at the close of New York Stock Exchange composite trading.

Without a bridge loan, Opel will run out of money during the third quarter, GM Europe President Carl-Peter Forster said on May 15. Aurora, Ontario-based Magna''s bid would focus on Russia, while Fiat''s plan would have a Latin American emphasis, Forster said in a May 15 interview. Fiat Chief Executive Officer Sergio Marchionne said in early May that he''s interested in an as-yet-undefined venture with GM in Latin America.

We will work with all parties over the next few days on how to proceed in terms of getting memoranda of understanding with the bidder or bidders, GM Europe''s Preuss said in a telephone interview today.

States Favor Magna

The four German states where Opel employs 25,000 workers predominantly favor Magna''s proposal, which shuns factory closures in Europe''s biggest economy, Hendrik Hering, economy minister of Rhineland-Palatinate, said today. Magna wants to turn Opel into an integrated automaker and supply it with components directly.

The supplier angle is extremely attractive. That''s something that Fiat is lacking, Hering said in a phone interview. At the same time, job cuts may be considerable under Magna, he added.

The offer from Fiat seems to have been well received by German regional governments, Italian Industry Minister Claudio Scajola told reporters today in Rome, without providing details. Germany''s Economy Ministry has no favorite bidder for Opel, Steffen Moritz, a spokesman in Berlin, said today.

Arnaud Denis, a spokesman for RHJ in Brussels, declined to comment. Daniel Witzani, a Magna spokesman based in Oberwaltersdorf, Austria, couldn''t be reached on his cell phone.

Fiat''s Labor Meetings

Fiat has been the most vocal suitor for Opel. Marchionne met with labor unions and German state politicians in the past week in an effort to defuse concerns about a plan that worker leaders have said may lead to losses of as many as 18,000 automotive-industry jobs in Europe.

It''s not just an Opel issue, Marchionne, who engineered a deal to control most of the assets of Auburn Hills, Michigan-based Chrysler, said in an interview yesterday. It''s a question of industry saturation. We need to handle this in an intelligent way in Europe. It doesn''t have to be as drastic and draconian as the American solution.

RHJ gets more than two-thirds of revenue from sales of automotive parts. The company is led by CEO Leonhard Fischer, who joined in 2007 from Credit Suisse, where he was head of European operations.

European Aid Needs

GM has said it needs 3.3 billion euros in aid from European governments to secure Opel''s survival. Merkel''s coalition government, facing elections on Sept. 27, is keen to avoid a collapse at Opel, which is Germany''s second-largest carmaker after Volkswagen AG and is identified by a lightning-bolt trademark. The Economy Ministry said on May 18 that it may send a negotiating team to the U.S. this week to seek an agreement on plans for Opel.

Opel is an integral brand of German carmaking, a true symbol of this country''s postwar recovery, Reinholz said. Governments have every reason to ponder all possible ways to try and rescue the company.

entry.author: By Chris Reiter
entry.headline: General Motors Received 3 Bids for Opel Unit, Spokesman Says
entry.body: General Motors Corp. has received three bids for its Opel unit in Germany, GM Europe''s spokesman Chris Preuss said in a telephone interview today.

entry.author: By Nadja Brandt
entry.headline: Electricite de France, Fiat, Shell, UCB: Europe Equity Preview
entry.body:
The following companies may have unusual price changes in European trading. Stock symbols are in parentheses, and share prices are from the previous close.

The Dow Jones Stoxx 600 added 0.5 percent to 211.75. The Dow Jones Stoxx 50 Index climbed 0.5 percent to 2,142.77. The Euro Stoxx 50 Index (SX5E), a benchmark for the nations using the euro, increased 1.1 percent to 2,487.17.

Electricite de France SA (EDF FP): Chief Executive Officer Pierre Gadonneix of Europe''s biggest power producer said the company is studying a possible sale of bonds to the public. The shares rose 93 cents, or 2.5 percent, to 37.55 euros.

Fiat SpA (F) : The carmaker made an offer for General Motors Corp.''s Opel unit. The shares climbed 14 cents, or 1 percent, to 7.98 euros.

Royal Dutch Shell Plc (RDSA) : Europe''s largest oil company has started to invite shareholders to discuss the rejection of an executive pay package after performance targets were missed. Shell gained 27 cents, or 1.5 percent, to 18.90 euros.

UCB SA (UCB) : Belgium''s biggest drugmaker by sales said Melanie Lee, executive vice president and president of UCB NewMedicines, will leave the company at the end of August. The drugmaker is looking for an external candidate to succeed Lee. UCB gained 68 cents, or 3 percent, to 23.52 euros.

entry.author: By David Pauly
entry.headline: General Motors Bondholders Might Take 20 Percent: David Pauly
entry.body:
It will be a shame if General Motors Corp. (GM) goes into bankruptcy proceedings simply because the U.S. government and the automaker''s bondholders can''t compromise.

General Motors -- or rather, government appointees pulling the strings -- offered owners of GM bonds a 10 percent equity stake in a restructured company in exchange for $27 billion in debt securities.

The bondholders objected, saying GM, until last year the world''s largest vehicle manufacturer, was discriminating against them in favor of its workers.

While the bondholders were voting against the proposal Tuesday, Detroit-based General Motors got the United Auto Workers to reduce to 17.5 percent the equity in the new GM to be owned by a union health-care trust. A previous agreement called for 39 percent. The UAW trust also gets $6.5 billion of preferred stock and a $2.5 billion note.

This new agreement gives GM and the government some wiggle room. Why not offer the bondholders a 20 percent stake in the remade General Motors? There would still be at least 60 percent left for the taxpayers, and maybe a dribble for current GM shareholders.

Wouldn''t that be preferable to the company going into bankruptcy? Chrysler LLC, the also-ran among U.S. automakers, sought court protection last month after its debt holders refused an offer of $2.25 billion for $6.9 billion in face value for their securities.

Not So Easy

While the Chrysler bankruptcy may be on a fast track to completion -- with its best assets sold to Italian automaker Fiat (F) SpA -- a court proceeding for the much bigger and far-flung General Motors might become an ordeal that benefits only the lawyers.

The U.S. already has invested $19 billion in General Motors and intends to dump in tens of billions more. Don''t waste money in court.

It''s a bit of mystery why GM bondholders have been so recalcitrant. They say the government is trampling on their property rights and prefer to take their chances with a bankruptcy judge.

Not all of the bondholders are speculators, as President Barack Obama said. But some of them are -- they bought GM debt on the cheap, betting on a windfall. That may make their legal pleading look less reasonable.

Longer-term holders of GM bonds may have a better case. Still, you wonder if they''re not just seeking cover for their own poor investments. GM bonds due in 2033, for instance, trade at between 5 cents and 7 cents on the dollar, compared with about 70 cents a year ago.

Something or Nothing

If a restructured General Motors can''t compete any better against foreign rivals than the old one, the bondholders wouldn''t benefit if they owned 100 percent of the company. On the other hand, if the new GM prospers, a 10 percent stake might wipe out bad investment memories.

An offer from the government now to give the investors a 20 percent stake would be subject to the same sort of reasoning. A bigger equity share in a continuing flop would have no more value than a smaller share. Still, if General Motors does have a profitable future, the bondholders could double up on their share of the earnings.

The deadline for GM to restructure outside of bankruptcy court is Monday. As a taxpayer, I''m willing to reduce my share of the government''s stake in the company if they offer the bondholders more. Do it. Fast.

(David Pauly is a columnist for Bloomberg. The opinions expressed are his own.)
